name: stoat

attributes.attribute: thought to have human characteristics such as living in families and holding rituals for their dead
dangerous, for their saliva could poison a full-grown man
not good luck to encounter a stoat when setting out on a journey, even a short one
one could turn the luck to good by greeting the stoat as a neighbor

sources: Ó hÓgain, Dáithí. Irish Superstitions. London: Gill & Macmillan, 1995.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: A small red-brown land mammal known as the stoat played a role in Irish mythology. Resembling a weasel, the stoat was attributed with human-like characteristics such as living in families and engaging in rituals for the deceased. They were also seen as mischievous and capable of theft, and their saliva was believed to be poisonous to humans. Encountering a stoat before embarking on a journey was considered unlucky, but this could be reversed by treating the creature like a neighbor.
